history.content:
you don't. you die.

----------------------

it depends on which classes you are going to take? if it's 162 + 3 other techs(like 164 and 151), probably refer to above comment.

__________________

Don't know about 4 techs, but from my experience, I know this:

2 techs + 1 breadth + research + teaching = die.

-------------------------------

Agree with dying comments and would strongly urge you reconsider. I don't even like taking 4 classes a semester, let alone 4 techs, let alone 4 CS techs. Like actually a stupidly awful schedule.

-------------------------------

I am doing 3 techs (1EE+1EECS+1CS) and 1 breadth plus research and grading. I am dying.

------------------------------

3 Techs + research + teaching  + clubs + grad school apps = time-management class

---------------------------------

I've done three CS upperdivs a semester for a while now, and that already eats up all my time. I can't imagine a fourth. 

----------------------------------

Late to the party but I've actually done this with 61B 61C 188 and 16A. I can confidently say:

Don't do it. You know the stories about Wall Street bankers working 100+ hours and getting hit crossing the street because they were so out of it? 4 Techs might just get you there.

children.subject: I've done 3 techs + 1 breadth + some EC's before - it was pretty rough, but I think 4 is totally possible if 1) you're smarter than average, and 2) you have no other obligations (no extracurriculars, no sports, no social clubs, no research, no teaching etc.)
It helps a LOT if you have a great group of people to study / learn with
I think 4 techs is way too much.

4 is too much, especially when one of them is a class like CS 162. If you're doing slightly easier classes like CS 168 or CS 186, it might be somewhat doable (still hellish). With a hard and work-intensive class like 162 you're just inviting trouble on yourself.

history.content: Like the students above, we don't recommend 4 techs. Feel free to speak to your adviser if you want to discuss further.

Due to the fact that I couldn't get into 162 this semester, I am planning to take 4 upper div CS classes the upcoming semester. To anyone who has taken a similar course load (and done well), how do you study? My previous schedules usually consisted of 2 techs and 1 to 2 breadths. To study for those classes, I basically did 80-90% of all past midterms and most of the textbook problems (where applicable) for my techs. Is it feasible to do the same things if I decide to take 4 techs?
history.subject: To people who took 4 techs a semester: how do you study?
